Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Understanding Cloud Security-Architectural Analysis Using Security Patterns
Award.AbstractNarration:
In recent years, cloud storage has provided ubiquitous and easily accessible remote data repository possibilities to clients. Applications of cloud computing require security assurances but there are many shortcomings in the current cloud security. Current approaches, like encryption, digital signatures and cryptographic keys generally negatively affect the performance of clouds. This project will identify a catalog of security patterns for the cloud computing environment. Security patterns provide design solutions to recurring security problems and define a way to express requirements and solutions concisely, as well as provide a communication vocabulary for designers. This project will be conducted in collaboration with Professor Hyoungshick Kim at the Security Lab, Sungkyunkwan University, South Korea. The collaboration affords a U.S. graduate student an opportunity to learn about unique cloud security strategies developed for the Korean cloud computing environment, enabling new insights to identify a set of security patterns.

Using Category Theory and an interpretive epistemology, this project will design a prototype to implement the PI?s pattern-based architectural solution to a widely used cloud Dropbox or Amazon S3. The research will provide a statistical data model to prove the statistical significance rendered by a new security pattern-oriented cloud design developed by the PI. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with National Research Foundation of Korea.

Project Title: Understanding Cloud Security - Architectural Analysis Using Security Patterns

Cloud computing has emerged as a fast-growing paradigm for storing, sharing and delivering services over the Internet. It provides its users a way to deal with information or data without investing on any new technology or resources. Although cloud computing environment is viewed as a promising Internet based computing platform, the security challenges it poses are also equally striking. Despite the development of cloud computing technology, security issues in clouds have to be addressed to a great extent. Cloud security is one of the major issues that hinder the adoption of cloud computing and slowing down its acceptance in many sectors. In this research, I provided an overview of cloud computing, in depth literature review on cloud security and privacy issues, as well as its research challenges. I have also explored security patterns as a viable solution to cloud security and explained them with a simple template. One of the targets in this research is to provide a better understanding of cloud security and highlight the security concerns that should be addressed to realize the maximum benefits of cloud computing. Security patterns allow cloud developers to use security measures without being security experts. Also, a cloud environment can be reengineered by using security patterns to add missing security features. In this research, I have provided a pattern-based cloud security framework as a good practical approach to ensure security features in cloud environment. 

Cloud computing provides enormous advantages in data storage and access, where the benefits outnumbers the weakness. Maintaining security and privacy in clouds became one major challenge and often viewed as weakness that hinders wide acceptance of cloud. Recently, security turned out to be an expected mandatory feature of cloud computing environment. Only if we could establish security and trust in clouds, we could continue benefitting cloud services. In this research, I have provided an overview of cloud computing, discussed its security challenges.  We have also suggested security patterns as a solution to tackle with the challenges of cloud security (Image - 1). I have also elaborated some important non-technical aspects that makes cloud security engineering process very difficult. I have introduced a simple model for security patterns in cloud environment and defined the characteristics of security pattern system. With a real life example and an effective classification scheme, this model can be remerged as a security pattern system. 

As a supporting evidence for my research, I have also provided a security ranking of a cloud environment by applying a quantitative methodology to the existing system (Image - 2). Cloud environment generally comprises many stakeholders like clients, cloud developers, vendors, and security experts. Through this ranking system, I insisted that before implementing any security protocol, inputs from all stakeholders should be considered. Security requirements of every client or organization may differ, and it becomes a challenge to cloud developers or security experts to include client side while making a decision. In this research, I have identified a metric system that starts from client’s input and eventually becomes the base model for threat ranking process. Our metric also shows, if threat ranking was merely done by software developers or security experts, it would have resulted in a different ranking scale, and that may not be a required service from client’s perspective.
